newsitem.title: CHINA: HOPEWELL AND BANGKOK DISCUSS SCALE-DOWN.
newsitem.headline: HOPEWELL AND BANGKOK DISCUSS SCALE-DOWN.

text.p: Hopewell Holdings has for the first time discussed scaling down its multi-billion dollar Bangkok mass transit project with Thai authorities in a bid to end a costly deadlock, a Hong Kong newspaper said on Saturday.
The HongKong Standard quoted business sources as saying senior Hopewell officials raised the proposal with Thailand's Ministry of Transport and Communications on Friday.
Hopewell officials were not immediately available to comment on the report in Hong Kong.

The proposal submitted to the ministry calls for at least a 10 percent cut in the 45 km project, clipping about two km each from its northern and eastern ends where passenger traffic would be lowest, the Standard said.
The scale-down would affect both road and rail services. Authorities had agreed to consider the proposal.
Hopewell has been working with bankers this month on a financing solution for the Elevated Road and Train System.
The schedule for the project financing has been affected by the decline of the Thai economy and the devaluation of the baht, making funding for any project in Thailand much harder.
As the project appeared bogged down, unpaid contractors stopped work in late July.
Only 17 percent of the project's first phase, supposed to be ready for the 1998 Bangkok Asian Games, has been completed.
The Thai government has threatened to cancel Hopewell's 30-year concession.
